name: Numazu Deep Sea Aquarium
description: What better place to build an aquarium for deep sea creatures than by Suruga Bay, Japan’s deepest bay with a maximum depth of 2,500 m? The Numazu Deep Sea Aquarium is the world’s first museum centered on deep sea species that live more than 200 m below the sea surface. The museum is best known for its three taxidermy specimens and two frozen specimens of coelacanth, a so-called “living fossil.” Other popular exhibits include a tank dedicated to organisms that inhabit Suruga Bay and a deep sea “planetarium” showcasing mesmerizing bioluminescent species. There is also a museum shop with toys, accessories, confectionary and other delightful souvenirs, all with a deep sea theme.
address:
〒410-0845　静岡県沼津市千本港町83055-954-0606（Numazu Deep Sea Aquarium）10:00-18:00 (last entry 30 minutes before closing)

name: View-O
description: Built in 2004, View-O is both a popular Numazu sightseeing spot and a gigantic gate designed to protect the city from tsunamis. At 40 m wide and 9.3 m tall and weighing 406 tons, it is one of the largest water gates in Japan and is designed to automatically shut within five minutes of a large earthquake occurring. Above the gate, 30 m off the ground, is an observatory that offers a 360-degree view of the surrounding landscape, including Mt. Fuji, the Hakone mountains, the Numazu Alps, Suruga Bay and Osezaki Cape. View-O is also lit up beautifully at night and makes for a popular dating spot where couples can take in the breathtaking nightscape together after a fresh seafood dinner in nearby Numazu Port.
address:
〒410-0867　静岡県沼津市千本1905-27055-964-1300（Numazu Tourist Association）10:00-20:00 (10:00-14:00 on Thursdays)None (with occasional exceptions for maintenance work)100 yen for adults, 50 yen for elementary school studentsApprox. 10 minutes by bus from JR Numazu Station. Get off at Numazu Port.
Approx. 25 minutes' drive from the Numazu IC on the Tomei Expressway.Available (reservations required for large buses)

name: Numazu Imperial Villa Memorial Park
description: The Numazu Imperial Villa was built in 1893 as a retreat for the Crown Prince at the time (future Emperor Taisho) as he recuperated from illness. In 1969, management of the villa and its grounds was taken over by Numazu City and they were reopened as the publicly accessible Numazu Imperial Villa Memorial Park. The main building was destroyed by fire during World War II but the West and East Annexes remain. The West Annex is a valuable example of Imperial Court architecture and offers a glimpse of early 20th-century Imperial life. With advance reservation, you can visit the East Annex or even rent it out for purposes such as practicing traditional Japanese culture or taking commemorative wedding photographs. Meanwhile, the villa’s Japanese garden is great for a leisurely stroll. Boasting a variety of flowers that blossom throughout the year, it provides a different vista each season. The garden also houses a café and a soba restaurant, and even offers a view of the sun setting over Suruga Bay.
address:
〒410-0822　静岡県沼津市下香貫島郷2802-1055-931-0005（Numazu Imperial Villa Memorial Park）9:00-16:30Basic admission: 100 yen for adults, 50 yen for elementary and junior high school students, free for infants.
Admission with access to the West Annex: 410 yen for adults, 200 yen for elementary and junior high school students, free for infants.Approx. 15 minutes by bus from JR Numazu Station. Get off at Goyotei-mae.
Approx. 25 minutes' drive from the Numazu IC on the Tomei Expressway.Available (free for cars and 1,040 yen for buses and minibuses)

name: Mt. Kanuki
description: At just 193 m tall and located around 1 km southeast of Numazu Station, Mt. Kanuki is an easily accessible and very hikeable mountain. Alongside Senbon Matsubara and Osezaki Cape, it is beloved by locals as a symbol of Numazu. While hiking, you can admire the seasonal flora, such as springtime cherry blossoms, hydrangeas in early summer, and autumn foliage. Near the top of the mountain is an elevated observation deck with beautiful views of the city, Suruga Bay and, on clear days, Mt. Fuji. There’s also a classic five-story pagoda and a rest area with shops and restrooms partway up the mountain.
address:
静岡県沼津市香貫Kanuki trailhead: Approx. 8 minutes by bus from JR Numazu Station. Get off at Reizanji. It's a 50-minute hike to the top.Koryodai Parking Lot
Nakase Parking Lot (8:00-17:30)

name: Heda Onsen
description: Situated along the western coast of the Izu Peninsula, Heda Onsen is a hidden hot spring area in the southwestern part of Numazu, beloved by those in the know. It is most famous for baths offering gorgeous views of the sun setting over Suruga Bay and, on clear days, Mt. Fuji across the sea. Thanks to its location right by Suruga Bay, Heda Onsen is also known for its fresh seafood, especially spider crab, the largest species of crab in the world, and other delicious deepwater delicacies. For overnight stays, a variety of accommodation options are available, from larger hotels and Japanese-style inns, to more cozy guesthouses. For day trips, a great option is to visit Roadside Station Kurura Heda, a facility with a day-use onsen, free public footbaths and exhibits showcasing local sightseeing spots, culture and history.
address: 〒410-3402　静岡県沼津市戸田1294-30558-94-5151（Kurura Heda）8:15-22:00Open year roundApprox. 70 minutes' drive from the Numazu IC on the Tomei Expressway via Mito and Ko to HedaAvailable

name: Senbon Matsubara
description: Senbon Matsubara is a beautiful forest made up of tens of thousands of pine trees, stretching around 10 km along the sea from the Kano River estuary to Tagonoura. Views of the evergreen pines, set against a snow-capped Mt. Fuji and dyed red by the sun setting over Suruga Bay are why Senbon Matsubara has been recognized as one of Japan’s top 100 beachside pine forests. It is also steeped in history, having been the site of a battle between the Takeda Clan and the Later Hojo Clan in the late 1500s. Senbon Matsubara was razed in the fighting, but was later painstakingly rehabilitated over five years by Zoyo Shonin, a famed Buddhist monk. Senbon Matsubara has also been celebrated by several eminent cultural figures, and plaques have been dedicated to them in part of the forest that has been turned into a park.
address:
〒410-0306　静岡県沼津市Approx. 10 minutes by bus from JR Numazu Station. Get off at Kannon-mae.Senbon Matsubara Park Free Parking LotThere is free parking at Senbon Matsubara Park.
(本字千本19190-1)

name: Numazu Cycle Station Shizuura East
description: A great way to see the city is by bike. Just rent one from Numazu Cycle Station Shizuura East, which is open every season and caters to customers of all ages. The most popular cycling route is a seaside course that takes you around the bay all the way over to Osezaki Cape, while offering wonderful views of Mt. Fuji and Suruga Bay. The route is around 18 km, takes about 70 minutes one way and is very manageable even for inexperienced cyclists. Besides bike rentals, Numazu Cycle Station Shizuura East also operates a skills park for BMXs and skateboards. The park is free to use and open to both experienced enthusiasts and novices alike. Practice tricks or master the basics at your own pace.
address: 〒410-0102　静岡県沼津市口野30-23055-934-4843（Sports Exchange Promotion Section (Numazu Cyclist Friendly Area Creation Project Team), Industry Promotion Division, Numazu City） FIEJA(East Shizuoka Cycling Map)
